A father of one of my competitors was trying to get my results thrown out because I beat his daughter. Mind you, we were in 2 different weight classes and age groups so we weren't competing directly against each other anyway. I have always had more of a muscular build especially in my upper body. I always wore lots of makeup to these meets to present as feminine as possible to avoid this and it still happens and it is annoying.

author: @kingoswav6984
text:
As a dark-skinned man, I've faced a lifelong battle with colorism. From childhood, I endured hurtful nicknames like "Black Cat" and "Dark Vader," which made me resent my skin and African features. Growing up as the only black family in a predominantly white neighborhood only heightened these insecurities, pushing me to idealize lighter skin.

In my teens, I began to reclaim my blackness and appreciate the beauty of my people. However, the insidious nature of colorism crept in, leading me to prioritize lighter-skinned partners. I feared passing on the same painful experiences to potential children, so I made the misguided decision to avoid dark-skinned partners.

As I entered my twenties, I started to confront and challenge these biases. I realized the richness and depth of beauty within the black community, regardless of skin tone. Yet, despite this realization, I still find myself struggling to shake off the remnants of my past prejudices in my dating life.

Now, in my thirties, I reflect on missed opportunities and the impact of my choices. I regret overlooking the stunning dark-skinned women who crossed my path, blinded by societal pressures and my own internalized biases. It's a painful reminder of the work that still needs to be done to dismantle colorism and fully appreciate the beauty of all shades within our community.

author: @baderinwa1
text: The pain that was inflicted upon me, throughout my childhood , came directly from my own mother. I was called black and ugly every day of my life, by my mother, who preferred my two lighter skinned sisters. I was born in the early fifties , and grew up in an all black community. Intra racial bias / colorism was pervasive. Most of the Black people in the community showed open disdain for dark skinned children, while fawning over children of a lighter hue. This maladaptive behavior also occurred in school. Most of the teachers showed preference for lighter skinned students, who were often the teacher‚Äôs favorite.

author: @cosinev1265
text:
It warms my heart to see the black community showing solidarity with the trans community. As a trans person it means the world to me.
Edit: Sorry about implicitly excluding black trans people. The intersection between these two communities is very important because black trans people bear the brunt of transphobia.

replies.author: @TroubledHousewife
replies.text: not trying to be rude or anything but, i really dislike the seperation that phrasing like this implies. the black community and the trans community should not be treated like inherantly seperate things. its like saying the black community and women coming together. it kinda alienates those of us who are in the middle and pushes the all too common notion of transness being a white thing.

replies.author: @casadastraphobia
replies.text: @TroubledHousewife off rip I felt the knee jerk desire to be like "is it that serious?" But after some thought you are definitely right. I think what they mean is hearing black cis voices is especially empowering because cis/trans black women have more in common than we don't, and black centered solidarity is especially wholesome at times. But implying inadvertently that black is separate from trans is a bad move because these realities have the capacity to intersect.

replies.author: @Twileen
replies.text: I hardly see black people talking about the LGBTQ+ in a good light

replies.author: @TreeHairedGingerAle
replies.text: I've spoken with trans women of all colors and they prove to be some of the loveliest, most thoughtful people I've ever met. As a Black cishet woman who has constantly been hounded and excluded for not meeting expectations of a very toxic misogynistic neighborhood, in favor for what *I* want and what moves and delights me, I recognize very deeply that both trans and cis women **are women,** and that we are both on the same side.

replies.author: @aaronholloway6060
replies.text: I'm a cisgender, gay Black man. Although I don't believe that souls are necessarily gendered, I will proudly say that I have the soul of a woman. Yes, I, too, support you unequivocally. üßúüèø‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüçâüêö

replies.text: @TroubledHousewife Yes! Every time I hear or read the traditional way that states "women and people of color" all I read is "women = white and people of color = men" because that is literally how the issues surrounding who and what is being addressed is how it's being "solved" ... never as "women of all racial backgrounds and men of color" or "Black and Brown women who experience issue in a different way than white women" and so on. Yes, some ways that the demographics of people is brought up in speech and writing is very cringe and still platforms/prioritizes the more privileged in the discussion.

replies.author: @URFTBOUND4LIFE
replies.text:
@TroubledHousewife The sad reality is that many black people express homophobic/transphobic ideas because of the misogyny that's never called out in our community. 
Very few black people are progressives  and lean on moderate or conservatives that vote Democrat due to decades of religious fundamentalism indoctrinating our people. 
It's why you have so many black men co-signing on far-right ideas (baring racism) or flat out ignoring issues that intersect within the community (transphobia, homophobia and misogyny). 
Sure we're not the only group that does it , but we're definitely the group that's lacking behind the most.

author: @OnryoFlow
text:
Really can't thank you enough for this video. I live in Louisiana where we've been fighting against anti-trans legislation for years. Two years ago, when fighting against the trans sports ban a young black trans woman with whom I'm in community testified arguing passionately that the bill may be motivated by transphobia, but the impacts would be felt by young black cis women whose femininity and right to compete would be challenged. Many of those young women wouldn't have the resources or support to fight back and would lose opportunities for athletics scholarships - often one of only a few ways that poor young black women have attending college.

There are many people, even within the trans community, who are unaffected by transmisogyny and don't understand how that unique form of oppression results in exclusion, marginalization, and often death. The fact that colorism and transmisogyny create these intersections is something that I truly hope more people can begin to understand.

author: @the.masked.one.studio4899
text: I‚Äôm trans masc and I didn‚Äôt realize how unsafe women of all types are until I started transitioning.  I haven‚Äôt even done much and I feel so much safer.  People ignore me, I‚Äôm not forced to smile or be polite anymore, I don‚Äôt get randomly hit on.  It‚Äôs up to all of us to keep all women and girls safe.  We start my taking their fears and worries seriously, by making sure that no one is hurting them, but also preparing for danger of all types.  üíñ

Big time. There was a time we had no brown people or barely on TV and media.
This is unrelated but I got interested by the Colorism topic because, sadly,  I think we have a lot of that in Mexico.

author: @IshtarNike
text: The drama over the prefix cis- is so embarrassing. As soon as I heard it it made sense. Why? I took chemistry and we use cis and trans to refer to different types of chemicals (it's a lot to explainin text but Google cos/trans isomers, it's actually super easy to understand). It maps perfectly on to the gender identity definition and was easy to understand. It's not a made up term. It's just an application of academic language that these people don't understand because they're uneducated and arrogant enough to assume they understood everything there was to know about science in secondary school lol. Same way they make the argument around sex being a pure binary. It's like arguing with a 3 year old who thinks the teachers live at school. Yes that may be what you think, and it may make perfect sense in your limited world, but you're still not correct.

replies.author: @Mamainbloom
replies.text:
Sex is not assigned at birth. Sex is established in the womb and observed at birth. Intersex conditions are rare and the rabbit whole that the gender fallacy movement created with that is too exhausting to visit right now. 

However, I am a born woman who doesn‚Äôt have a gender identity. I am not non binary. I am a gender abolitionist because gender no longer is a synonym for sex which it previously was defined as. I do not an identify as a woman. I am a woman. I do not identify as black. I am black. I do not identify as a mother. I am a mother. I do not identify as a two legged person. I have two legs. 

Black people have selective respect for science and will never do the research behind the governing bodies that pushed these new gender terms into our everyday speech.

replies.author: @sentientnatalie
replies.text: @Mamainbloom "The sun revolves around the Earth, blasphemers!"

replies.author: @sasentaiko
replies.text:
My parents were teachers so I didn‚Äôt know some kids think teachers live at school! Ahahahahahaha that‚Äôs a good one. 
Anyway it‚Äôs not really about whether they remember chemistry‚Ä¶ the bigots don‚Äôt like losing their sense of being ‚Äúthe norm‚Äù, which to them means ‚Äúthe only valid possibility.‚Äù They prefer to be as unmarked as possible. In their minds, both trans and cis are markers and therefore potentially shameful or exotifying. So on one hand, it‚Äôs extremely important to them that they are not trans (ie cis), but they‚Äôll take it as an insult if you use that as a modifier, like ‚Äúcis accountant‚Äù. It‚Äôs not as inflammatory an issue with terms like straight/het and white, but it‚Äôs still there. People freak out if you call someone‚Äôs only niece a ‚Äústraight niece‚Äù but it‚Äôs somehow fine to call someone‚Äôs only aunt a ‚Äúgay aunt‚Äù. Or watch the fireworks if you ‚Äúunnecessarily‚Äù use white as a modifier for someone (eg an actor), but they don‚Äôt mind saying ‚ÄúAsian-American actor‚Äù.

author: @kropotkinnie
text:
So based.

As a trans guy I always worry for black trans folk alongside myself, but it extends to the whole of the black community because much of the tactics used to disqualify trans womanhood are also just as easily used to disquality black womanhood. As a trans guy I have it easier (although that does mean I still experience sexism and get patronized/treated like a baby instead of colored as a monster) but it became so evident during all this sports scandal bs that the stuff being lobbed at trans women is purposefully tailored to also hit black cis women.

It's no shocker this stuff is lobbed at women of color the most, cis or trans. It's always about hurting women in general, especially minorities who don't fit the white American pageant queen mold. To a lot of transphobes, the criteria for not being trans is whiteness. If you're not white and gender conforming, you are transgender in their eyes, and that is why so much transvestigation bullshit targets black women. They'll never see black women as women because this never had anything to do with what's between your legs, and always had everything to do with what is attractive and easily controlled by a white man and what isn't.

author: @redthunderbird8117
text: Colorism as the factual description is globally has more evidence that it may began in Asia way before the white man made contact with Africa or Asia. It is often depicted in Asian culture and religion before the famous constructs that divided Jews and Italians, maybe.  It is more certain to say Western colorism.  Hip-hop  has been been controlled or influenced by dark brown skin men's preferences for beauty so, it is there influence that has strongly exacerbated colorism and promoted colorism. Black women did not fight against this and there were plenty of opportunities. I always wondered about Oprah and her role to , but then again... Who is her man and do we assume there is no colorism involved given her history...  Did Ebony, Essence do enough? Colorism in the American Black community has a long history but hip-hop made it truly par for course favoring, not Drake, but ambiguously Black and Black adjacent influencers... The IG progeny of the video vixen( common knowledge,)... Still black women have power... And they do not use it. I really think that the deeper it truly goes... It critiques everyone. Make up itself emphasizes a European and Asian look for Black these days... I have seen black darker skin African women without the artificial esthetics and just a natural look... That has no colorism at all. I think it is very clear that a male having a white parent is as n advantage, but outside that... The  receipts of favoritism are harder to pin down by region. So, many light skin men in the spotlight do not have two black parents anymore...  Steph Curry and who else?
